procedure.summary: Cut the strawberries into ⁄2 in (1.3 cm) slices and put them in a saucepan.
procedure.description: Rinse 1 pound (450 g) of strawberries and use a paring knife to cut off the stems. Then slice each strawberry into ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) thick slices and put them into a saucepan. You can use frozen strawberries for this recipe. Just thaw the strawberries in the refrigerator until they're easy enough to slice.

procedure.summary: Stir in the sugar, lemon juice, and optional vanilla.
procedure.description: Add 1/3 cup (67 g) of granulated sugar to the saucepan along with 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of lemon juice. If you'd like a deeper flavor, add 1 teaspoon (4.9 ml) of vanilla. Stir until the berries are coated with the sugar. The lemon juice won't make the strawberry glaze taste sour. Instead, it will give the glaze a bright, fresh flavor.

procedure.summary: Bring the strawberry glaze to a boil.
procedure.description: Turn the burner to medium so the strawberries start releasing liquid. Stir them occasionally to prevent them from burning and continue to heat the strawberries until they bubble vigorously. The strawberries will break down as they cook so there's no need to mash them.

procedure.summary: Simmer the glaze for 20 to 25 minutes.
procedure.description: Turn the burner down to medium-low and keep the lid off of the saucepan. Stir the glaze frequently as it simmers and becomes a heavy syrup. The syrup will thicken as some of the liquid evaporates.Variation: If you prefer a very thick strawberry glaze, whisk 1 tablespoon (9 g) of cornstarch with 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of cold water. Then stir the mixture into the hot glaze about 5 minutes before it's finished cooking and stir constantly. The amount of time it takes to cook will depend on how much moisture there was in the strawberries.

procedure.summary: Turn off the burner and cool the glaze to room temperature.
procedure.description: Transfer the strawberry glaze to a bowl or storage container and leave it to cool until it reaches room temperature. This should take about 30 minutes.

procedure.summary: Serve the strawberry glaze with breakfast or dessert.
procedure.description: Spoon the room-temperature glaze over pancakes. If you prefer, refrigerate the glaze until it's cold and then pour it over cheesecake or ice cream. To store the strawberry glaze, put it into an airtight container and refrigerate it for up to 3 to 4 days. The strawberry glaze will thicken even more as it's refrigerated.
